newsitem.title: USA: Sequana discovers asthma gene - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Sequana discovers asthma gene - WSJ.

text.p: Sequana Therapeutics Inc is expected to announce on Wednesday that it has discovered a gene that could eventually lead to better treatments for asthma, the Wall Street Journal said.
In Wednesday's electronic edition, the Journal said Sequana's studies indicate that between 10 percent and 20 percent of asthma sufferers carry the gene.

"This gene discovery defines for us a fundamental cause of asthma and will help us to identify novel points of therapeutic intervention," said Christoph Hohbach, the worldwide director of research at Sequana's partner, Boehringer Ingelheim International GmbH.
Nevertheless, any drug to be developed from the discovery would take between five years and 10 years to bring to market, the Journal said.

Sequana President and Chief Executive Kevin Kinsella said details of the asthma gene discovery will not be published until Boehringer Ingelheim is confident that the disclosures would not jeopardize its patent rights.
Some 100 million people have asthma around the world.
